subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4
msgSnippet: I concur with Simon - our company policy is JSE4 development, and I don t see JSE5 happening any time soon. I know of very few developers here in the UK that
messageBody:
I concur with Simon - our company policy is JSE4 development, and I
don't see JSE5 happening any time soon. I know of very few developers
here in the UK that are working for companies completely au fait with
JSE5, and Mustang is only a month or so around the corner!

What benefits would converting JUnit 4 to JSE4 bring, beyond flexibility
in test naming and ordering?

BTW, is there still any development effort intended for JUnit 3.8.x? If
so, I'd like to volunteer! :)
--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

Simon Chappell wrote:
> On 9/14/06, Robert Wenner <robert.wenner@...> wrote:
>> On Tuesday 12 September 2006 09:30, Mark Levison wrote:
>>> Unfortunately some of us work in corporate
>>> environments where use of Java 1.5 will take at least another couple of
>>> years (we only just dropped support for Java 1.3). Can you for see
>>> support for Java 1.4 are must we look to TestNG to fulfill our needs?
>> You cannot even install Java 5 on a test machine yourself?
>> I understand if you need to support a Java 1.4 for the production code,
>> but what prevents you from running your tests on Java 5?
>
> Corporate policy! At many sites in the US of A, including my current
> and several previous ones, will often specify that users not be given
> administration rights to their workstations and, further, that the
> download and install (in case you get around the lack of admin rights)
> of any unauthorised software (and they usually get picky down to the
> version numbers) is a dismissible offence. This doesn't make sense,
> applied to developers, but corporate policies are a very real fact of
> life for many of us. This is why many of us are not able to switch,
> even for non-production and develoment machines.
>
> Simon
>
